knowledge_graph.title: Angiography
knowledge_graph.description: Angiography or arteriography is a medical imaging technique used to visualize the inside, or lumen, of blood vessels and organs of the body, with particular interest in the arteries, veins, and the heart chambers.

inline_images.title: Angiogram: What It Is and What It Shows

related_questions.question: Are you awake with an angiogram?
related_questions.snippet: Your coronary angiogram takes place in a hospital room that looks like an operating theatre. You'll be taken to the procedure room and be asked to lie on a narrow table. You will be awake throughout the procedure, and before it begins your doctor may offer you sedation to help you relax.
related_questions.title: Coronary Angiogram - "Angio" - St Vincent's Heart Health

related_questions.question: What happens if a blockage is found during an angiogram?
related_questions.title: AI Overview
list: Angioplasty and Stenting: If a blockage is found and the cardiologist deems it suitable, they can immediately perform an angioplasty. This procedure involves inserting a catheter with a balloon into the blocked artery. The balloon is inflated to widen the artery and improve blood flow. A stent, a small mesh tube, is often placed at the site of the blockage to keep the artery open.

Other Treatment Options: Depending on the severity and location of the blockage, and the patient's overall health, other treatment options may be considered. These can include:  Medications: Medications can be used to manage cholesterol, blood pressure, and blood clots, which can help prevent or manage blockages.  Lifestyle Changes: Lifestyle modifications, such as dietary changes, exercise, and smoking cessation, can also play a significant role in managing heart health and blockages.
Medications: Medications can be used to manage cholesterol, blood pressure, and blood clots, which can help prevent or manage blockages.
Lifestyle Changes: Lifestyle modifications, such as dietary changes, exercise, and smoking cessation, can also play a significant role in managing heart health and blockages.

Delayed Treatment: In some cases, the cardiologist may choose to delay treatment with angioplasty and stenting, particularly if the blockage is complex or if the patient's condition requires further evaluation.

Possible complications: While angioplasty and stenting are generally safe procedures, potential complications can include bleeding, infection, or damage to the blood vessel. Serious complications are rare.

related_questions.question: What will they do in an angiogram?
related_questions.snippet: An angiogram procedure involves injecting contrast material (dye) that your provider can see with an X-ray machine. Images on a screen show blood flow and blockages in your blood vessels. Your provider will give you medicine to make sure you're relaxed and comfortable. Most people receive sedation.
related_questions.title: Angiogram: What It Is and What It Shows

related_questions.question: Is it painful to have an angiogram?
related_questions.snippet: The angiography procedure a long, thin, flexible tube (catheter) is inserted into the artery and is carefully guided to the area being examined – you may feel some pushing and pulling when this is done, but it should not be painful.
related_questions.title: What happens - - - Angiography - NHS

text_blocks.snippet: An angiogram is a medical imaging procedure used to visualize blood vessels. It involves injecting a special dye (contrast agent) into the blood vessels and then using X-rays to create detailed images of the vessels' structure and blood flow. This helps doctors identify blockages, narrowed areas, or other abnormalities in arteries and veins.
snippet_highlighted_words: a medical imaging procedure used to visualize blood vessels

list.title: Diagnosis:
list.snippet: Angiograms help diagnose various vascular conditions, including heart disease, stroke, and peripheral artery disease.

list.title: Treatment Guidance:
list.snippet: They can guide minimally invasive procedures like angioplasty (widening narrowed arteries) and stenting (placing a small tube to keep an artery open).

list.title: 1. Preparation:
list.snippet: The patient is typically given a light sedative and the area where the catheter will be inserted (usually the groin or wrist) is numbed with a local anesthetic.

list.title: 2. Catheter Insertion:
list.snippet: A thin, flexible tube called a catheter is inserted into a blood vessel and carefully guided to the area of interest.

list.title: 3. Contrast Injection:
list.snippet: The contrast dye is injected through the catheter, making the blood vessels visible on X-ray.

list.title: 4. Image Acquisition:
list.snippet: X-ray images are taken as the dye flows through the blood vessels, revealing their structure and any abnormalities.
Coronary Angiogram: Focuses on the heart's blood vessels.
Cerebral Angiogram: Focuses on the brain's blood vessels.
Pulmonary Angiogram: Focuses on the lungs' blood vessels.
CT Angiogram (CTA): Uses CT scans and contrast dye for imaging.
MR Angiogram (MRA): Uses MRI and contrast dye for imaging.

text_blocks.snippet: While generally safe, angiograms carry some risks, including:

list.snippet: Bleeding or bruising at the catheter insertion site .
Allergic reaction to the contrast dye .

text_blocks.snippet: Important Note: The information provided is for general knowledge and should not be taken as medical advice. It is crucial to consult with a healthcare professional for any health concerns or before making any decisions related to your health or treatment, according to the British Heart Foundation.
